Total CVOC mass in the source zone was greatly decreased by 86% two and half years following EZVI injection using pneumatic fracturing injection. • Mobilization of DNAPL during or after EZVI injection could occur, which presents challenges in conducting an accurate performance evaluation. Contamination of saturated and unsaturated zones of aquifers by chlorinated volatile organic compounds (Cl-VOCs) such as tetrachloroethene, trichloroethene and chloroform is a well known phenomenon that has resulted in widespread pollution problems around the world (e.g., Lenhard et al., 1995; Conant et al., 1996; Smith et al., 1996; Choi et al., 2002; Laor et al., 2003; Ronen et al., 2005; Graber et al., 2008). VOCs present a unique problem, in so much as they spread readily in the subsurface in several phases: the vapor phase, the aqueous phase and the non-aqueous phase. Transport in each of these phases contributes in its own way to exacerbating the contamination and increasing the risks to different receptors. The transport mechanisms of Cl-VOC vapors through bulk unsaturated porous media have been the subject of numerous investigations (e.g., Marrin and Kerfoot, 1988; Falta et al., 1989; Massmann and Farrier, 1992; Smith et al., 1996; Jellali et al., 2003; Tillman and Smith, 2005; Choi and Smith, 2005; Sorek et al., 2008).
